titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Ellen Terry note, between 1878-1902. RL.11632
titlestmt.author: Megan E. Lewis

publicationstmt.publisher: David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2018-06-15 16:20:13 -0400.

repository.corpname: David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library

did.abstract: Collection comprises a single autograph note on Lyceum Theatre letterhead (5"x8"). The actor Ellen Terry writes to "Olga" to schedule a social engagement. She writes, "I'm much grieved to hear of you mother ..." and sends "best remembrances" to Olga's husband. Dame Ellen Terry, considered the leading Shakespearean actor of her time, was a member of the company at London's Lyceum Theatre from 1878-1902.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Ellen Terry (1847-1928) was the leading Shakespearean actor of her time. She was born into a family of actors and started her career as a child. In 1878, she joined Henry Irving's company at the Lyceum Theatre. She portrayed many celebrated roles with that company through the end of her tenure there in 1902.

userestrict.head: Use Restrictions
userestrict.p: The copyright interests in this collection have not been transferred to Duke University. For more information, consult the copyright section of the Regulations and Procedures of the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library.

acqinfo.head: Provenance
acqinfo.p: The Ellen Terry note was received by the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library as a purchase in 2015.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Identification of item], Ellen Terry note, David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library, Duke University.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Processed by Megan E. Lewis, June, 2018.

scopecontent.head: Collection Overview
scopecontent.p: Collection comprises a single autograph note on Lyceum Theatre letterhead (5"x8"). The actor Ellen Terry writes to "Olga" to schedule a social engagement. She writes, "I'm much grieved to hear of you mother ..." and sends "best remembrances" to Olga's husband.

Ellen Terry (1847-1928) was the leading Shakespearean actor of her time. She was born into a family of actors and started her career as a child. In 1878, she joined Henry Irving's company at the Lyceum Theatre. She portrayed many celebrated roles with that company through the end of her tenure there in 1902.
